Progress Report  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Technical Assistance Number: 4814 
October 2007 
 
 
 
 
 
India: Technical Assistance Cluster for Project 
Processing and Capacity Development 
(Financed by the Government of the United Kingdom)

CURRENCY EQUIVALENTS 
(as of 31 August 2007)  
 
Currency Unit – Indian rupee/s (Re/Rs) 
Re1.00 = $0.024 
$1.00 = Rs41.11 
 
 
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
ADB   –  Asian Development Bank 
BIP  –  Board information paper 
CTA   –  component technical assistance 
DEA   –  Department of Economic Affairs 
DFID   –  Department for International Development 
INRM    –  India Resident Mission 
JTF   –  Joint Task Force 
SARD   –  South Asia Department 
TA   –  technical assistance 
TAC    –  technical assistance cluster 
 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Targeting Classification – General intervention 
Sector – Multisector 
Themes – Sustainable economic growth, governance, capacity development 
 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Vice President   L. Jin, Operations Group 1 
Director General   K. Senga, South Asia Department (SARD) 
Director     T. Kondo, Country Director, India Resident Mission (INRM), SARD 
 
Team leader    P. Dayal, Principal Economist, INRM, SARD 
Team member  S. Viswanathan, Senior Social Economics Officer, INRM, SARD

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  This  Board  information  paper  (BIP)  reports  on  the  implementation  progress  of  the 
technical assistance cluster (TAC), TAC 4814-IND,1 for the period 1 February 2007–31 August 
2007. It has been prepared in accordance with paragraph 26 of the TAC paper, which requires 
submission of a consolidated report, every six months, to the Board of Directors (the Board) and 
the  management  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  on  the  progress  of  TAC 
implementation. The last BIP, for the period 25 July 2006–31 January 2007, was circulated to 
the Board in March 2007. The BIP for the TAC was also shared with the Government of India 
(the Government) and the U.K. Department for International Development (DFID). The next 
consolidated BIP for the TAC is due in March 2008. 
 
2.  ADB approved TAC 4814-IND for $15 million to the Government on 30 June 2006. The 
TAC is financed by the Government of the United Kingdom through its DFID. The TAC, provided 
in response to the Government’s request, fast-tracks high-priority infrastructure projects and 
supports improvements in project preparedness, project design, and implementation capacity 
under  ADB’s  India  program.  The  Board  had approved  the  inclusion of  project  preparatory 
technical assistance (TA) activities under the TAC on an exceptional basis.2 
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLUSTER 
 
A.   Impact and Outcome  
 
3.  The  TAC  aims  at  enhancing  project  preparedness,  improving  project  design,  and 
strengthening effective implementation capacity under ADB’s India program. It will reduce the 
need for stand-alone TA projects and will increase the Government’s ownership of follow-up 
projects. The TAC will improve the quality and delivery of the more than $3 billion ADB program 
of  assistance  for  India.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  for  the  TAC  is  provided  in 
Appendix 1.  
 
B.   Methodology and Key Activities  
 
4.  As a cluster grant facility, the TAC finances several component technical assistance 
(CTA) projects under the ADB India program for 2006–2009. These CTAs support a range of 
project  preparatory  and  capacity-building  activities,  including  feasibility  studies,  preliminary 
designs,  safeguard  assessments,  capacity  development,  procurement  support,  detailed 
engineering designs, and project reports.  
 
5.  The original TAC comprised 15 CTAs from the India program for 2006–2009 with an 
overall allocation of $15 million, including TAC administration costs. Subsequently, based on the 
recommendations  of  the  Joint  Task  Force  (JTF)3  and  approval  of  the  CTA  papers  and 
implementation plans by the director general of the South Asia Department (SARD), the TAC 
has been expanded to include 24 component TAs. The revised list of CTAs included under the 
TAC is as follows:  
                                                 
1  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance Cluster to India for Project Processing and Capacity Development. Manila 
(TA 4814-IND, financed by the Government of the United Kingdom).  
2  TACs were introduced in ADB. 1997. Review of the Bank’s Technical Assistance Operations. Manila. However, 
TACs were restricted to advisory TA projects.  
3 The JTF is the TA steering committee that deliberates on addition, deletion, and amount enhancements and 
reductions of CTAs. It also reviews progress on these CTAs. On the basis of recommendations by the JTF, formal 
approval for CTAs is obtained from the director general of the South Asia Department.

3
D.   Implementation Arrangements 
 
8.  The TAC is executed by the DEA and administered by the India Resident Mission for a 
period of 30 months, from July 2006 to December 2008. The JTF consists of the joint secretary 
and the director of the DEA, the country director and sector specialists from the India Resident 
Mission, and SARD sector directors and mission leaders responsible for the CTA projects. 
International and national consultants are engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the 
Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). 
 
III.  PROGRESS IN IMPLEMENTATION 
 
A.  Progress against Goals and Overall Impact 
 
9.  Five Development Projects Take Off Within a Year. The TAC has directly contributed 
to detailed project preparedness through relevant CTAs for five loans amounting to $1.59 billion 
approved in 2006 and 2007. These loans are for the Madhya Pradesh State Roads II Project 
($320 million), the Madhya Pradesh Power Sector Development Investment Program ($620 
million), the Jammu and Kashmir Urban Sector Investment Program ($300 million), the North 
Karnataka  Urban  Sector  Investment  Program  ($270  million),  and  the  Kolkata  Environment 
Improvement Project (Supplementary Financing) ($80 million). Project preparatory and detailed 
design activities for another 14 loans estimated at $3.7 billion are ongoing for possible approval 
in 2007–2009. Estimates indicate that each $1 million spent under the TAC has the potential to 
leverage development investment of more than $350 million. 
 
10.  Support  to  New  Partner  States  and  Pro-Poor  Sectors:  Capacity  Building  and 
Advisory Support. The Government has recognized the flexibility and responsiveness the TAC 
offers  in  relation  to  improving  project  preparedness  under  ADB’s  India  program.  It  has 
appreciated  the  TAC’s  flexibility  in  addressing  the  advisory,  capacity–building,  and  project 
preparatory requirements of new sectors and of the comparatively less developed states of 
Bihar, Chattisgarh, and Jharkhand and of the northeastern region. The TAC is also supporting 
emergent priority areas of the Government, as reflected by CTAs on agribusiness infrastructure, 
tourism infrastructure, flood and riverbank erosion control, natural resource management, clean 
energy, and infrastructure financing.  
 
11.  The  TAC  has  been  providing  capacity  development  support  to  many  of  these  less 
developed states and new subsectors. Prominent among the new sectors supported under the 
TAC are commodity futures, municipal infrastructure financing, wetland management, trade and 
investment infrastructure in the northeastern states, and housing finance.  
 
12.  Enhanced Client Ownership and Responsiveness. The TAC has been responsive to 
the  Government’s  need  for  comprehensive  project  preparation,  improved  efficiency,  and 
enhanced ownership of project preparation and implementation under ADB’s India program. 
The TAC modality and the provisions for a JTF have enabled the Government to directly 
participate and be involved in the planning and close monitoring of project preparation activities 
under ADB’s India program. 
 
13.  Considerable Time Savings. The TAC has  significantly improved the efficiency of 
preparing, processing, and approving TAs, aided by the TAC’s simplified procedure. Within 12 
months of TAC effectivity, 22 CTAs have been endorsed for implementation. The 24 CTAs 
currently included under the TAC will also result in improving the planning and operational 
capacity of the executing agencies of the proposed follow-up loans.

4   
 
B.  Outputs and Activities Under the TAC 
 
14.  Twenty-Four CTAs for $14.88 Million Included Under the TA Cluster.  Based on JTF 
or DEA endorsement, the total number of CTAs included under the TAC has increased from 15 
to 24, as of 31 August 2007. This includes the four CTAs that were included under the TAC 
during the 1 February 2007–31 August 2007 reporting period. Appendix 2 presents the revised 
list of CTAs included under the TAC.  
 
15.  Twenty-Two  CTAs  for  $13.98  Million  Prepared,  Processed,  and  Approved  for 
Implementation. Since TAC effectivity on 25 July 2006, the director general of SARD has 
approved a total of 22 CTAs for $13.98 million for implementation. This includes the 10 CTAs 
that were prepared, processed, and approved for implementation during the reporting period. 
Only two CTAs worth $0.9 million are currently under preparation. Their inclusion is subject to 
approval of their implementation plan or TA paper by the director general of SARD.  As of 31 
August 2007, the 22 CTAs had committed nearly $8 million and disbursed $1.5 million. 
 
16.  Three CTAs Completed. Implementation has been completed for three CTAs: (i) the 
National  Hydroelectric  Power  Corporation  Capacity  Development  Project,  (ii)  the  Madhya 
Pradesh Power Sector Investment Program, and (iii) project preparation support for the Madhya 
Pradesh  State  Roads  Project  II.  Implementation  for  seven  more  CTAs  is  expected  to  be 
completed by December 2007. Implementation of the remaining 14 CTAs will be completed by 
June 2008, ahead of the TAC completion date of 31 December 2008. 
 
17.  JTF  Deliberations.  The  JTF  has  been  proactively  guiding  and  overseeing  the 
programming and implementation of the TAC. The JTF met 4 times during the first 12 months of 
TAC implementation to steer and streamline the composition of the TAC. Based on inputs from 
ADB staff, executing agencies, and the DEA, the JTF reviewed the relevance, implementation 
schedule, and financial allocation of each CTA with respect to the India program for 2006–2009. 
It recommended changes in the composition of the TAC that included canceling 3 CTAs, adding 
12 new CTAs, increasing the financial allocation of 3 CTAs, and reducing the financial allocation 
of 6 CTAs. These revisions (Appendix 2) reflect the Government’s project scheduling and 
sectoral priorities with respect to ADB’s operations and program in India.  
 
IV.  CONCLUSION  
 
18.  The TAC has highlighted the importance of supporting project readiness for timely and 
cost-effective delivery of ADB’s India program. By doing so, the TAC has established a close 
link between country programming and project preparation activities.  
 
19.  Implementation  of  the  TAC  is  on  track  to  deliver  its  intended  outcomes,  namely, 
improving project implementation readiness, strengthening local capacity and ownership, and 
enhancing the efficiency of project preparation and implementation. Most CTAs were prepared 
so as to be completed by 31 December 2007, even though the original completion date for the 
TAC  was  31  December  2008.  This  was  done  because  of  the  anticipated  closure  of  TAC 
financing from the DFID by December 2007. However, based on an assessment of  the work 
remaining to be done for effective operationalization of projects in the India program, the CTA 
project officers have been given an option of extending their CTA completion dates to 30 June 
2008.

5
20.  DFID financing of the TAC will close on 31 December 2007. Financing of CTAs beyond 
31  December  2007  could  either  be  from  DFID’s  proposed  partnership  modality,  which  is 
currently under preparation and is subject to internal DFID approval, or from ADB’s internal TA 
resources. If the DFID partnership modality does become operational on 1 January 2008 as 
anticipated, this would mean that the TAC would be financed under the new facility as of that 
date. If DFID financing does not materialize, ADB would need to find and allocate internal TA 
resources to finance the CTAs beyond 31 December 2007. This would be in accordance with 
ADB’s commitment to provide a TAC of $15 million equivalent to the Government of India.
